form.steps:
1. Set up a weight plate or a platform to stand on, creating a deficit of 1-4 inches. 
2. Stand on the platform with your feet hip-width apart, the barbell positioned directly over your mid-foot. 
3. Hinge at your hips and knees simultaneously, ensuring your back is straight and your core is engaged. Grip the barbell slightly wider than shoulder-width, using an overhand or mixed grip. 
4. Inhale deeply, brace your core, and maintain a neutral spine. 
5. Drive through your heels, extending your hips and knees to lift the barbell off the ground. Keep the barbell close to your body throughout the movement. 
6. Once you reach a standing position, pull your shoulders back and maintain an upright posture. 
7. Reverse the movement by hinging at your hips and knees, lowering the barbell back to the platform with control.

form.Back: Keep your back straight throughout the entire lift, maintaining a neutral spine. Avoid rounding or arching your back.
form.Core: Engage your core muscles to stabilize your spine and prevent injury. Keep your abdominal muscles tight.
form.Hips: Initiate the movement by pushing your hips back, not by squatting down.
form.Bar Path: Keep the barbell as close to your body as possible throughout the lift. This ensures optimal leverage and reduces stress on your lower back.
form.Head and Neck: Maintain a neutral head position, looking straight ahead. Avoid tilting your head up or down.

commonMistakes.Rounding the Back: One of the most common mistakes is rounding the back during the lift. This puts excessive stress on the lower back and can lead to injury. Ensure your back is straight throughout the movement.
commonMistakes.Squatting Instead of Hinging: Another common mistake is squatting down instead of hinging at the hips. The deficit deadlift should primarily target the glutes and hamstrings, not the quads. Focus on pushing your hips back and maintaining a straight back.
commonMistakes.Using Too Much Weight: Using too much weight can compromise form and increase the risk of injury. Start with a weight you can lift with proper form and gradually increase the load as you get stronger.
commonMistakes.Not Controlling the Descent: Lowering the barbell too quickly can put stress on your joints and muscles. Control the descent by slowly reversing the movement and maintaining tension in your muscles.

comments.Increased Range of Motion: The deficit deadlift increases the range of motion compared to the conventional deadlift, leading to greater muscle activation and potential strength gains.
comments.Improved Starting Strength: By increasing the difficulty of the lift off the floor, deficit deadlifts can help improve your starting strength in the conventional deadlift.
comments.Grip Strength: Deficit deadlifts can also challenge your grip strength due to the increased range of motion and the need to hold the barbell for a longer duration.
comments.Programming Considerations: Deficit deadlifts are typically programmed as an accessory exercise to the conventional deadlift. They can be performed 1-2 times per week, depending on your training experience and recovery capacity.

alternativesAndVariations.Conventional Deadlift: The standard deadlift variation, performed without a deficit. It targets similar muscle groups but with a shorter range of motion.
alternativesAndVariations.Rack Pulls: Performed with the barbell elevated off the ground, reducing the range of motion and allowing for heavier loads. Rack pulls primarily target the upper back and traps.
alternativesAndVariations.Sumo Deadlift: A deadlift variation with a wider stance and a more upright torso. Sumo deadlifts emphasize the inner thighs and hips.
alternativesAndVariations.Hex Bar Deadlift: Performed using a hex bar, which allows for a more neutral grip and a more balanced weight distribution. Hex bar deadlifts can be a good option for lifters with lower back issues.

deficit-deadlift.tempo: 2011 (2 seconds lowering, 0 seconds pause at the bottom, 1 second lifting, 1 second pause at the top)
